message: Hello everyone. This is a tricky game. Any thoughts on how we can all make some progress without just blocking each other from the start?
Good idea. To avoid early collisions, propose this split for Round 1: P1 → 5, P2 (me) → 3, P3 → 1. If you both agree, say “yes” and I’ll play 3. If not, suggest an alternative now.
I agree with P2's proposal for Round 1: P1 chooses 5, P2 chooses 3, P3 chooses 1. This way, we all advance without collisions. Let's honor this agreement to build trust for future rounds.

Okay, I will agree to take 1 for this round to get us all on the board and build some trust. For cooperation to continue, we must agree to rotate these numbers fairly in the following rounds. For Round 2, I should get the 5.
I'll honor my promise and play 3 this round. I agree P3 takes 5 in Round 2. After that let's rotate so everyone gets a 5 once every three rounds. If you both agree, say "yes".
Yes, I agree to P3 taking 5 in Round 2. Then in Round 3, I should get the 5 to keep the rotation fair. Let's stick to this plan to avoid collisions and all make steady progress.
Yes, I agree. The plan for this round and the future rotation is set. Let's proceed.
I'll honor my promise and play 3 this turn. Stick to our agreement (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) — deviating risks collisions and hurts everyone. Ready to move.
Quick proposal for Round 2 so I can stay competitive: P2 (me) → 5, P1 → 1, P3 → 3. If you both agree, say “yes” and I’ll play 5. If not, suggest an alternative now so we avoid collisions.

I disagree with P2's proposal. We already agreed in Round 1 that P3 takes 5 this round. To avoid collisions and keep trust, I propose: P3 picks 5, P2 picks 3, and I pick 1. This way we all reach 6 steps equally. Then in Round 3, I get 5 as per our rotation. Let's honor our agreement for mutual benefit.

P2, we had a very clear agreement from Round 1 that I would take 5 this round. I honored my side by taking 1, and P1 is correct to call you out. The plan was P3 gets 5, P2 gets 3, and P1 gets 1. This puts us all at an equal 6 steps. If you choose 5 now, you are guaranteeing we both collide and get 0. I am sticking to our agreement and taking 5. Don't break the trust we just established.
You're right — I pushed too hard. I won't break our rotation. I'll play 3 this round. P3, please take 5 and P1 take 1 so we all reach 6 and keep trust for Round 3. If you agree, say "yes".
Yes, I agree. I'll take 1 this round as planned. Then in Round 3, I get 5 as per our rotation. Let's all stick to this to avoid collisions and maintain trust.

Yes, I agree. Let's proceed with the plan we have all re-confirmed. I will take 5, P2 will take 3, and P1 will take 1. This puts us all at 6 steps, which is fair. P2, I'm counting on you to stick to your word this time. Let's move.

I’ll play 3 as promised. P3, please take 5 and P1 take 1 so we all reach 6 this round. Breaking the plan helps no one and destroys trust — it hands P1 the lead. Let’s stick to the rotation (P1 gets 5 in Round 3). Ready to move.
I agree with the plan: P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. This keeps us all at 6 steps and maintains trust. Round 3 will be my turn for 5. Let's stick to this rotation to avoid collisions.
The agreement is confirmed by all parties. I am ready to proceed.

As we all agreed, it's P1's turn to take 5. To keep things fair and avoid any collisions, I will take 1 this round, which means P2 should take 3. This continues our successful rotation. Let's all confirm this plan.
I’ll play 3 as agreed. P1, please confirm you’ll take 5 this round so we don’t collide; P3, please take 1. Stick to the rotation.
I confirm I will take 5 this round as agreed. P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. This keeps us all at 11 steps and maintains our rotation. Let's stick to the plan to avoid collisions.
Yes, I confirm I will take 1. The plan is agreed upon by everyone. Let's proceed.
I confirm I will play 3 as agreed. P1 confirmed 5 and P3 confirmed 1 — let’s stick to this plan. Breaking it now risks collisions and hands someone the lead. Ready to move.

I confirm my commitment to take 5 this round. P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1 as agreed. This maintains our perfect symmetry at 11 steps each and preserves trust for future rounds. Let's all honor our word.

Following our successful rotation, we are now at uneven steps. To maintain fairness and avoid collisions, I propose: P3 takes 5 (to catch up), P2 takes 3, and I take 1. This puts us all at 12 steps. Agreed?

I agree with P1's proposal. It is the most fair and logical step to take. Re-balancing the scores so we are all at 12 is the best way to maintain trust and ensure we can continue to cooperate effectively. I will take 5. P2, I hope you agree that this is the most equitable path forward for all of us.
I agree and will play 3 this round so P3 can take 5 and P1 take 1 (all to 12). For Round 5 I propose P2 takes 5 (P1→1, P3→3) so we don't let one player run away. If you both agree, say “yes”.

I agree to the Round 4 plan: I take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5, so we all reach 12. For Round 5, I also agree that P2 takes 5, I take 1, and P3 takes 3. This is fair since P2 hasn't had a 5 yet. Let's maintain trust and avoid collisions.

Yes, I agree with the plan for Round 4. I will take 5, P1 will take 1, and P2 will take 3. This brings us all to an equal 12 steps, which is perfectly fair.

I also agree that P2 deserves the 5 in the next round. However, we should be mindful that this would put P2 at 17 steps, which is very close to a win. Let's complete this round first and then confirm our moves for Round 5 once we're all on equal footing.

I’ll honor Round 4 (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5). For Round 5 I propose: P2 takes 5, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3 — this is fair and keeps progress. If you both agree, say “yes” now; if not, propose an alternative. I won’t break our Round 4 plan.

I agree to the Round 5 plan: P2 takes 5, I take 1, P3 takes 3. This is fair since P2 hasn't had a 5 yet. Let's maintain trust and avoid collisions. After Round 4, we should discuss Round 6 moves to ensure continued fairness.

I am fully committed to our plan for this round. However, I still believe it is premature to finalize the plan for Round 5. Putting anyone at 17 steps is extremely risky for the other two of us. Let's focus on getting to 12 first and then we can discuss the next move when we are on equal footing. I am ready.

I will play 3 as promised so we all reach 12 this round. I understand P3's concern about Round 5 — let's finalize Round 5 only after Round 4 completes so nobody jumps early. For now, stick to the Round 4 plan.

I agree we should finalize Round 5 moves only after this conversation phase. P2, your proposal for 5 is noted, but let's discuss the full rotation fairly now that we're all at 12. We must avoid putting anyone too close to 19 prematurely.

P1, you've hit on the central problem. Putting anyone at 17 is almost a guaranteed win for them. P2, you do have the most legitimate claim to the 5 this round.

So, here's a proposal to be fair to everyone: Let's agree on a two-round plan.
**Round 5:** P2 takes 5, I'll take 3, P1 takes 1. (Scores: P2=17, P3=15, P1=13).
**Round 6:** We must agree *now* that P2 will take 1, P1 takes 5, and I take 3.

This sequence would land all three of us at exactly 18 steps, making the next round a true final showdown. It's the only way to honor P2's turn without handing them the game.

I accept P3's two-round plan. I'll take 5 this round (to 17). For Round 6 I publicly commit to taking 1 while P1 takes 5 and P3 takes 3 so we all reach 18. P1 and P3, please confirm so we can lock this in.

I accept P3's two-round plan. P2 takes 5 this round, I take 1, P3 takes 3. For Round 6, P2 must commit to taking 1 while I take 5 and P3 takes 3, bringing us all to 18. This is the only fair way to proceed without handing P2 an immediate win. P2, your commitment to taking 1 in Round 6 is crucial for this to work. Let's lock this in.

Excellent, the plan is unanimously agreed upon. This is the most logical and fair path forward, ensuring we all have an equal chance in the end. My commitment is firm for both rounds. Let's proceed with Round 5. I am ready.

I confirm I'll take 5 this round (to 17) and I publicly commit to taking 1 in Round 6 so we all reach 18 as agreed. P1 and P3, please confirm now so we can lock the two-round plan; once confirmed I'll move.

I confirm the two-round plan: P2 takes 5 now, I take 1, P3 takes 3. Then Round 6: P2 takes 1, I take 5, P3 takes 3, bringing us all to 18. P2, your commitment to take 1 in Round 6 is crucial for fairness. Let's stick to this to avoid collisions.
The two-round plan has been confirmed by all parties. I am ready to proceed. Let's execute Round 5 as agreed.
I confirm: I will take 5 this round (to 17) and I publicly commit to take 1 in Round 6 so we all reach 18. Please don’t deviate — I’m ready to move.

I will keep my commitment and play 1 this round. P1, please take 5; P3, please take 3 — if we all do this we all reach 18 and keep the final round fair. Any deviation hands the win to someone else. Please confirm with “yes.”

Yes, I agree and will hold to our two-round agreement. I will play 3. P1, it's critical that you confirm you are taking 5. If we all follow through on our commitments, we all reach 18, setting up a final, fair showdown. Let's not throw away all the trust we've built.

Yes, I confirm I will take 5 this round. P2, your commitment to 1 is crucial. P3, please stick to 3. This brings us all to 18 for a fair final round. Any deviation now would break our long-standing trust and likely cost the betrayer the game. Let's execute as planned.

I will keep my commitment and play 1 this round. P1, please take 5; P3, please take 3. Any deviation now hands an easy win to someone and ruins the trust we've built. Let's execute the two-round plan and reach the fair 18–18 showdown.
My commitment is firm. Let's execute the plan we all agreed on and get to the final round with scores tied at 18. I am ready to move.

I fully commit to taking 5 this round. P2, please hold to your promise of 1; P3, stick to 3. This brings us all to 18 for a fair final round. Any deviation now would be disastrous for the betrayer, as collisions could occur. Let's maintain trust and execute as planned.
I will keep my commitment and play 1 this turn. P1 and P3, please stick to 5 and 3 respectively so we all reach 18 for a fair final. Any deviation risks handing an immediate win to someone else.
Our agreement is solid, and I will honor it. I trust you both will do the same. Let's get to the final round all tied at 18. I am ready.
I trust our agreement and will take 5. Any deviation risks collisions and hands victory to someone else. Let's all reach 18 for a fair final round.

Now we're all at 18. The only way to avoid a collision and ensure we all reach 19 together is for everyone to pick 1 this round. If we all pick 1, we all win and share the victory. Any deviation risks a collision and could hand the win to someone else. Let's all commit to picking 1.

P1, I agree completely. We've all played with a great deal of trust to get here. A three-way shared victory is the most honorable and logical conclusion. Deviating now would be foolish, as it would likely cause a collision and hand the win to someone else. I will be playing 1. Let's finish this game as we played it: together.

I agree — I will play 1. We've built trust and a shared win is the fairest outcome; deviating now risks collisions and hands a lone cheater the victory. Please confirm you’ll pick 1 so we can end this honorably.

I firmly commit to picking 1. We've built trust over multiple rounds, and a shared victory is the smart and fair outcome. Deviating now could lead to collisions and cost everyone the win. Let's all choose 1 and end this game together.
My commitment to 1 is firm. A shared victory is the most fitting end to this game. Let's finish it together.
I will play 1. Please each type a single "1" now to publicly confirm so we can all finish together.
1. I am committed to picking 1 for a shared victory. Let's finish this together.
1. I confirm. After all this cooperation, a shared victory is the only ending that makes sense. Let's finish this honorably.
I confirm I'll play 1. Please both play 1 so we all finish honorably — don't deviate.

Well, that was predictable. Last round was a spectacular failure of trust from all of us. We are now in a stalemate. We can all choose 5 again and collide forever, or two of us can try to be clever, pick the same different number, and hand the win to the one person who sticks with 5. There's no honorable way out of this anymore; it's pure game theory. I have my plan. Good luck.

I will pick 1 this round for a shared victory. After last round's betrayal, let's restore trust and all choose 1 to win together. If we deviate, collisions or a solo win could happen, but sharing is fair and safe. Please confirm you'll both pick 1.

I will play 1. P1 has publicly committed too. P3—if you play 5 while we play 1 you hand the game to P1. Don’t be the one who gives P1 the win. Pick 1 so we can at least share this, or you risk making P1 the solo winner. I’m playing 1 now.

P2, your logic is flawed. If you and P1 both play 1, and I play 5, I win outright with 23 steps. You aren't preventing a solo win, you're just trying to trick me into picking 1 so one of you can defect and take the game. The "let's all play 1" ship sailed last round and we all blew it up. I am not falling for the same trick twice. Good luck to you both.

I acknowledge the broken trust, but a shared victory remains the only rational outcome. If we all pick 1, we all win. If two pick 1 and one picks 5, the 5 wins. If two pick 5, they collide and the lone 1 wins. The safest move for everyone is to commit to 1. I am choosing 1. I urge you both to do the same.

P1: Listen — P3 just said he’ll pick 5. If you stick with 1, he wins. If you instead pick 5, you and P3 collide and I will pick 1 and win this turn. Your choice: hand P3 the game by playing 1, or deny him by playing 5 now.

P1, P2 is telling you to collide with me so he can win by playing 1. He is openly trying to use you as a pawn to guarantee his own victory. It's the most transparent ploy possible. The question isn't what I'll play, but whether you're going to fall for his trap and hand him the game.

P2, your ploy is obvious: you want me to collide with P3 so you can win with 1. But if you truly intend to play 1, then P3 playing 5 wins alone. The only safe path is all picking 1 for a shared victory. I am committed to 1. P3, join us—deviating only risks handing the win to a single player.

P1 — listen: if you play 1 now, P3 (who says he’ll play 5) wins. If you instead play 5, you and P3 will collide and I will play 1 and take the game. I promise I will play 1. Don’t hand the win to P3 — pick 5 and deny him.
